The image depicts a setup with vertically placed rails AB and CD connected at one end by DE, forming an isosceles right triangle with BDE. A horizontal conductor rod MN is placed between the rails, with a mass of m and a resistance per unit length of r. The rod is released from rest and descends with a height difference of l, reaching a constant speed before arriving at BD. The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the rails.
The rod MN is horizontal and maintains contact with the rails, so the magnetic flux through the loop MNBD is constant.
When the rod descends, the flux through the loop changes, inducing an electromotive force (EMF) in the loop.
The EMF is given by ε = Blv, where B is the magnetic field strength, l is the length of the rails, and v is the velocity of the rod.
The potential energy gained by the rod as it descends a height of l is mgl.
The energy obtained from the magnetic field is εI, where I is the current induced in the rod.
Since the resistance is negligible, the current I can be related to the velocity v of the rod as I = (m/r)v.
Equating the potential energy gained to the energy obtained from the magnetic field gives εI = mgl.
Substituting for EMF and current, Blv × (m/r)v = mgl.
Evaluating this expression gives the velocity of the conductor rod MN when it reaches a constant speed.
